title: 106_s1673
content: The Act titled "Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 1999" amends Title 18, United States Code to include a new chapter for the protection of unborn children. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 1999 adds a new chapter to Title 18, United States Code, protecting unborn children. Section 1841 addresses causing death or bodily injury to an unborn child, making it a separate offense with similar punishment as if the injury occurred to the mother. Proof of knowledge of the victim's pregnancy is not required. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 1999 establishes a new offense for causing harm to an unborn child, with penalties similar to those for harming the mother. Knowledge of the victim's pregnancy is not necessary. The death penalty cannot be imposed for this offense. The Act references various sections of Title 18 for enforcement. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 1999 creates a new offense for causing harm to an unborn child, with penalties similar to those for harming the mother. It references multiple sections of Title 18 for enforcement, including specific subsections that exempt certain situations from prosecution. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 1999 defines terms related to unborn children, specifying that a child in utero is a member of the species homo sapiens at any stage of development. The term "unborn child" refers to a child in utero. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 1999 defines terms related to unborn children, specifying that a child in utero is a member of the species homo sapiens at any stage of development. The term "unborn child" refers to a child in utero. Section 3 of the act pertains to the military justice system. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 1999 defines terms related to unborn children, specifying that a child in utero is a member of the species homo sapiens at any stage of development. Section 919a of the Uniform Code of Military Justice addresses causing death or bodily injury to an unborn child, with separate offenses and punishments outlined. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 1999 specifies that causing harm to an unborn child is a separate offense, with penalties similar to those for harming a human being. The Act does not require proof of knowledge about the pregnancy or intent to harm the unborn child. The death penalty is not applicable for offenses under this Act. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 1999 identifies specific sections of the law related to prosecution for offenses against unborn children. It clarifies that prosecution is not permitted for certain situations, such as abortion with consent, medical treatment, or actions of the pregnant woman. The Act defines terms like "child in utero" and "unborn child" to encompass all stages of development. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 1999 defines "unborn child" as a child in utero. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 1999 defines "unborn child" as a child in utero, causing death or bodily injury.
